title.title: Proclamation from Wyoming Territory Governor J. A. Campbell; November 4, 1875

msIdentifier.collection: Civil War & Reconstruction Governors of Mississippi, Main Collection

gloss.p: Celebrated since 1789, Thanksgiving became a federal holiday in the United States on June 28, 1870 and is celebrated annually on the fourth Thursday of the month of November. It originated as a day set aside for the giving of thanks for a bountiful harvest but also functions as a celebration of American nationalism. For instance, it is often celebrated with large gatherings centered around a meal consisting of foods indigenous to North America, such as turkey, potatoes, squash, and corn, among other foods. (Wikipedia) Throughout the American Civil War, both the Union and Confederacy celebrated days of thanksgiving at home and in the field. Its celebration was a vital component of Union and Confederate nationalism, and connected both region's to its colonial era history. Touted as a way to unify a divided country, President Abraham Lincoln issued a Thanksgiving Day Proclamation on October 3, 1863 that made it a federal holiday. (Wikipedia; "Proclamation, 1863," Gilder Lehrman Institute of American History)

Operating at the national level, the United States Executive Department consists of the President, the Vice President, and the Cabinet. The President functions as Commander in Chief, and is responsible for the appointment of members of the Cabinet and other federal agencies, and the enforcement of legislation approved by Congress. The duty of the Vice President is to assume the presidency if necessary. The Cabinet is composed of presidentially appointed heads of federal organizations who act as advisors to the President. ("The Executive Branch," The White House)

catDesc.term: United States--Executive Department. Office of the President

gloss.p: Operating at the national level, the Office President of the United States is the head of the executive body and is responsible for assuming the role of the Commander in Chief, appointing members of the Cabinet and other federal agencies, and the enforcement of legislation approved by Congress. The first United States President was elected in 1789. ("The Executive Branch," The White House)

Created in 1890, the executive branch of the State of Wyoming is headed by the Governor and also includes the Secretary of State, both of which are elected to serve a four-year term. The executive department also consists of the Wyoming State Treasurer, the Wyoming Attorney General, and the Wyoming Superintendent of Public Instruction. The primary duties of the executive branch of the State of Wyoming are to ensure the laws of the state are preserved, enact new legislation, and to command the militia. (Wikipedia)

catDesc.term: Wyoming--Office of the Secretary of State

gloss.p: Created in 1890, the Office of the Secretary of State of Wyoming is an elected position with a four-year term. The Secretary of State of Wyoming is tasked with overseeing the Administrative Services Division, the Business Division, the Executive Office, the Compliance Division, the Elections Division, and the Technology Division. (Wikipedia; "Duties of the Office of Secretary of State," Wyoming Secretary of State)
Located in Laramie County, Wyoming, Cheyenne was founded in 1867. (Wikipedia)
The Territory of Wyoming was established July 25, 1868. Admitted as the 44th state, Wyoming achieved statehood July 10, 1890. (Britannica)

div.fw: Proclamation from Wyoming Territory Governor J. A. Campbell; November 4, 1875

p.b: BY J. A. CAMPBELL GOVERNOR OF THE TERRITORY OF WYOMING.

p.hi: THE PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES HAVING DESIGNATED
As a day of Thanksgiving and Praise, I recommend the faithful observance of the day by all the people of Wyoming, in accordance with the usual and time-honored custom.

p.b: "GIVE THANKS UNTO THE LORD, FOR HE IS GOOD, FOR HIS MERCY ENDURETH FOREVER."

p.hi: IN TESTIMONY WHEREOF, I have hereunto set my hand, and caused the Great Seal of the Territory to be affixed. Done at Cheyenne, this, Fourth day of November, in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and seventy-three.

div.p:
JASON B. BROWN,
Secretary of Territory.
